byline.contributor: Michael Cieply and Brooks Barnes contributed reporting.

abstract: Tribune Publishing Company's decision to fire Los Angeles Times publisher Austin Beutner triggers backlash both in Los Angeles and among paper's staffers, who viewed Beutner's plan for making paper more independent and city-focused as way forward after years of layoffs and management turnover; while Tribune's cost-cutting centralization strategy has yielded more than $1 million in revenue, many former and current Times employees feel company must invest more money to keep paper running.
lead_paragraph: Austin Beutner’s departure as publisher, a position he had held only a year, widened a divide between The Los Angeles Times and its corporate parent in Chicago.

headline.main: A Firing at The Los Angeles Times Focuses Discontent
headline.print_headline: Firing at Los Angeles Times Focuses Discontent

snippet: Austin Beutner’s departure as publisher, a position he had held only a year, widened a divide between The Los Angeles Times and its corporate parent in Chicago.
